questions.text: What is the lower limit of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
The pharynx extends from the base of the skull (basiocciput and basisphenoid) to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It continues as the oesophagus.

Pharynx is a 12-14cm long conical fibromuscular tube forming the common upper part of the air and food passages.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the hypopharynx. Which of the following sites will not be involved?
questions.solution:
Epiglottis is part of the supraglottic larynx.

The hypopharynx is made of 3 parts:

  • Pyriform sinus
  • Posterior Pharyngeal Wall 
  • Post-cricoid region

questions.text: On oral examination of a patient with recurrent upper respiratory tract infection, you notice that the Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes is enlarged. Which of the following is not included in Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.
The masses are:

  • Adenoids or nasopharyngeal tonsils
  • Palatine tonsils or simply tonsils
  • Lingual tonsils
  • Tubal tonsils
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of  MALT structures?
questions.solution:
MALT stands for mucosal associated lymphoid tissue. Retropharyngeal lymph nodes are not a part of it. 

The rest of the structures are a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

questions.text: You are the junior resident in the ENT department performing a posterior rhinoscopy procedure on a patient. Where will you locate the pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube?

choices.text: 2.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
1.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
2.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate
1.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate

questions.solution: The pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube is situated in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx 1.25cm behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: You are observing a tissue sample from the nasopharynx through an electron microscope. Which of the following epithelium will you see?
questions.solution:
The nasopharynx is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. Functionally, it is the posterior extension of the nasal cavity.

Other parts of the pharynx are lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution: Fossa of Rossenmuller is the most common site for carcinoma in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma which has spread to the sinus of Morgagni.  Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected due to the spread into this space?
questions.solution:
Descending pharyngeal artery does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni and hence least likely to be affected. All the other options are contents of the sinus of Morgagni. 

The sinus of Morgagni is a space between the base of the skull and the upper free border of the superior constrictor muscle.

The structures passing through the space are:

  • Eustachian tube
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Ascending palatine artery- branch of the facial artery

Trotter's triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by:

  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Ipsilateral immobility of the palate
  • Neuralgic pain

questions.text: Which of the following structures is present in the oropharynx?
questions.solution:
Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissues seen in the base of the tongue, hence a part of the oropharynx. 

Oropharynx includes:

  • Base of tongue
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Vallecula
  • Anterior and posterior pillars
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall

The pharyngeal end of the pharyngotympanic tube and fossa of Rosenmuller is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

The pyriform fossa is a part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with oropharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes does the sentinel  node belong to?
questions.solution:
The jugulodigastric node is the sentinel lymph node and belongs to the level 2 group of lymph nodes.

This is the node enlarged in both tonsillitis and base of tongue carcinoma as lymphatics from the oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
questions.solution:
Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. 

It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during deglutition or speech.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman suffering from iron deficiency anemia presents to you with difficulty in swallowing. On examination, glossitis and cheilitis are observed. There are oesophageal webs seen on direct laryngoscopy.  Which of the following is the most common site for carcinoma to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in women suffering from Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome/ Patterson Kelly Brown syndrome is a condition that can occur in people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anemia. The triad seen in these patients:

  • Post cricoid webs
  • Glossitis
  • Angular cheilitis

Post cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to you with a foreign body sensation in his throat. On examination, you notice the impaction of a fishbone in his pyriform sinus.  Which group of lymph nodes will you find enlarged in case of its infection?
questions.solution:
Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of lymph nodes.

The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain.

Pyriform sinus lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It forms the lateral channel for food. The rich lymphatic network of pyriform fossa explains the high frequency of nodal metastasis seen in carcinoma of this region.
